type_forge.typing.naming

This module provides utilities for obtaining standardized names and representations of Python types. It ensures consistent naming conventions and human-readable type descriptions across the Type Forge system.

Core functionalities include: - Generating standardized type names for both built-in and custom types - Handling complex generic types with nested parameters - Identifying primitive types for special treatment - Providing clean string representations of type hierarchies - Converting between different type representation formats - Analyzing type structures for naming consistency

These utilities form the foundation for consistent type naming and presentation throughout the Type Forge ecosystem, supporting both programmatic type operations and human-readable documentation.

type_forge.typing.naming.are_types_compatible(source_type, target_type)[source]

Check if two types are compatible.

Determines if a value of source_type can be used where target_type is expected.

Parameters:

  • source_type (Any) – The source type to check

  • target_type (Any) – The target type to check against

Returns:

True if the types are compatible, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> are_types_compatible(int, float)
True
>>> from typing import List
>>> are_types_compatible(List[int], List[float])
False
>>> from typing import Any
>>> are_types_compatible(str, Any)
True

Note

Compatibility checks consider subclass relationships and type hierarchies.

type_forge.typing.naming.describe_type(typ)[source]

Get a detailed description of a type.

Returns a dictionary with comprehensive type information.

Parameters:

typ (Any) – The type to describe

Returns:

A dictionary containing type details

Return type:

Dict[str, object]

Examples

>>> details = describe_type(int)
>>> details['name']
'int'
>>> details['category']
'primitive'

Note

Provides deep type structure analysis for complex inspections.

type_forge.typing.naming.format_type_annotation(typ, for_docstring=False)[source]

Format a type for use in annotations or docstrings.

Generates properly formatted type strings for different contexts.

Parameters:

  • typ (Any) – The type to format

  • for_docstring (bool) – Whether the type is being formatted for a docstring

Returns:

The formatted type annotation

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> from typing import List, Optional
>>> format_type_annotation(List[int])
'List[int]'
>>> format_type_annotation(Optional[str], for_docstring=True)
'str or None'

Note

When formatting for docstrings, uses more human-readable forms.

type_forge.typing.naming.get_fully_qualified_name(typ)[source]

Get the fully qualified name of a type.

Returns the complete module path and type name.

Parameters:

typ (Any) – The type to get the name for

Returns:

The fully qualified name of the type

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> get_fully_qualified_name(int)
'builtins.int'
>>> import collections
>>> get_fully_qualified_name(collections.defaultdict)
'collections.defaultdict'

Note

Useful for serialization and type lookup across module boundaries.

type_forge.typing.naming.get_generic_args(typ)[source]

Get the type arguments of a generic type.

For generic types like List[int], returns the inner types (int).

Parameters:

typ (Any) – The generic type to inspect

Returns:

The type arguments of the generic type

Return type:

Tuple[Any, …]

Examples

>>> from typing import List, Dict
>>> get_generic_args(List[int])
(int,)
>>> get_generic_args(Dict[str, int])
(str, int)
>>> get_generic_args(int)
()

Note

Returns an empty tuple for non-generic types.

type_forge.typing.naming.get_type_category(typ)[source]

Get the category of a type.

Categorizes a type into one of: primitive, container, composite, callable, or special.

Parameters:

typ (Any) – The type to categorize

Returns:

The category of the type

Return type:

TypeCategoryLiteral

Examples

>>> get_type_category(int)
'primitive'
>>> get_type_category(list)
'container'
>>> get_type_category(Union[int, str])
'composite'
>>> get_type_category(Callable[[int], str])
'callable'

Note

Categories help determine how types should be processed or displayed.

type_forge.typing.naming.get_type_name(typ)[source]

Get the name of a type.

For simple types, returns the type name. For generic types, includes the parameter types.

Parameters:

typ (Any) – The type to get the name for

Returns:

The name of the type

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> get_type_name(int)
'int'
>>> from typing import List
>>> get_type_name(List[int])
'List[int]'
type_forge.typing.naming.is_container_type(typ)[source]

Check if a type is a container.

Container types include list, dict, set, tuple, etc.

Parameters:

typ (Union[type, Any]) – The type to check

Returns:

True if the type is a container, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

type_forge.typing.naming.is_generic_type(typ)[source]

Check if a type is generic.

Generic types include List[T], Dict[K, V], etc.

Parameters:

typ (Any) – The type to check

Returns:

True if the type is generic, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> from typing import List
>>> is_generic_type(List[int])
True
>>> is_generic_type(int)
False
type_forge.typing.naming.is_optional_type(typ)[source]

Check if a type is Optional[T].

Detects if a type is Union[T, None] or Optional[T].

Parameters:

typ (Any) – The type to check

Returns:

True if the type is Optional, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> from typing import Optional
>>> is_optional_type(Optional[int])
True
>>> is_optional_type(int)
False
>>> is_optional_type(Union[str, None])
True

Note

Optional[T] is equivalent to Union[T, None].

type_forge.typing.naming.is_primitive_type(typ)[source]

Check if a type is primitive.

Primitive types are basic types like int, str, float, bool, etc.

Parameters:

typ (Union[type, Any]) – The type to check

Returns:

True if the type is primitive, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

type_forge.typing.naming.normalize_type(typ)[source]

Normalize a type representation.

Converts type aliases to their canonical form for consistent representation.

Parameters:

typ (Any) – The type to normalize

Returns:

The normalized type

Return type:

Any

Examples

>>> from typing import List, Sequence
>>> normalize_type(List[int]) == list[int]  # Python 3.9+ syntax
True

Note

Normalization ensures consistent type representations across the system.
